from-alpha-to-omega/a-o-general-patterns.title: A-O General Patterns
from-alpha-to-omega/a-o-general-patterns.description:
While it is helpful to have paradigms memorised, there is a lot of information to take in, and learning the patterns can help to speed up the process. Endings generally match the definite article EXCEPT: -ος in the masculine nominative singular
-ον in the neuter nominative and accusative singular
-α in the neuter nominative and accusative plural common feminine -ος nouns include: ὁδος (road)
νοσος (sickness) The ε, ι, ρ Rule
IF: the stem ends in ε, ι, or ρ
THEN: use ᾱ instead of η in the singular Long vowel (ᾱ/η) For long vowel feminine nouns where the ε, ι, ρ rule DOESN'T apply, follow the definite article exactly
Where the rule applies, use ᾱ instead of η in the singular Short vowel (α) For short vowel feminine nouns where the ε, ι, ρ rule DOESN'T apply (θᾰ́λᾰττᾰ), remember that the vowel changes from α to η in the genitive and dative Masculine Has the 2nd declension -ου ending in the genitive singular ὅδε, ἥδε, τόδε (this, the nearer) is just the definite article + δε
οὗτος, αὕτη, τοῦτο (this, the further) only differs from the expected in the nominative masculine and feminine, where the initial τ is dropped
ἐκεῖνος declines according to the 2-1-2 pattern of endings
The 2-1-2 Pattern
the 2-1-2 pattern referrs to a group of adjectives which use 2nd declension endings for masculine and neuter, and 1st declension endings for feminine The present and future tenses use the primary endings
The imperfect uses the secondary endings The future is formed by adding -σ- between the stem and ending (sometimes causing a change of consonant) σ + π, β, φ = ψ
σ + κ, γ, χ = χ
Dental consonants (δ, θ, ζ) are dropped The imperfect is formed: augment + stem + ending
the augment is an ε added to the beginning of a word μι-verbs are also called athematic verbs because they are formed without adding an ο/ω to the ending (this ω/ο is the theme vowel in the tenses covered so far) Very generally: accusative: motion towards
genitive: motion away from
dative: no motion
from-alpha-to-omega/a-o-general-patterns.sourcePath: Personal/Github Pages/From Alpha to Omega/A-O General Patterns.md

from-alpha-to-omega/a-o-print.html.title: A-O Print
from-alpha-to-omega/a-o-print.html.description:
The Definite Article
2nd Declension Nouns
1st Declension Nouns
Demonstratives (this/that): ὅδε, οὗτος, ἐκεῖνος
Adjectives
Ω-verbs - Present, Future, and Imperfect
εἰμί
Prepositions: Governing Cases
The ε, ι, ρ Rule
IF:
THEN: The present and future use the primary endings
The imperfect uses the secondary endings Allows you to practice the forms you have learned so far with examples

headers.heading: ω-Verbs: Present Active Indicative, Infinitive, and Imperative
ω-Verbs: Future Active Indicative and Infinitive

from-alpha-to-omega/a-o-print-summary.ht.title: A-O Print Summary
from-alpha-to-omega/a-o-print-summary.ht.description:
Where do the endings of 2nd declension nouns differ from the article? (circle above) What is the ε, ι, ρ rule? Which group of 1st declension nouns declines most similarly to the definite article?
a) Long-vowel feminine nouns where the ε, ι, ρ rule DOESN'T apply
b) Long-vowel feminine nouns where the ε, ι, ρ rule DOES apply
c) Short-vowel feminine nouns where the ε, ι, ρ rule DOESN'T apply
d) Short-vowel feminine nouns where the ε, ι, ρ rule DOES apply
e) Masculine 1st declension nouns Which group of 1st declension nouns does θαλαττα fall under? Why is this important to know? Which forms of the masculine 1st declension nouns are the same as the 2nd declension nouns? (give 2 forms) Which forms of οὗτος, αὕτη, τοῦτο begin with τ? what is the '2-1-2' pattern of endings? name one adjective which follows this pattern Which tenses (that you have learned) use the primary endings, and which use the secondary? Give the sound change from adding -σ- when forming the future: σ + π =
σ + γ =
σ + δ = when does the augment lengthen? What directional movement is generally implied by each case: accusative: genitive:
dative:
from-alpha-to-omega/a-o-print-summary.ht.sourcePath: Personal/Github Pages/From Alpha to Omega/A-O Print Summary.md

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_minCollapseDepth.description: Only allow outline items to be collapsed if they are at least this many levels deep in the tree.

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
